description:
This adds a first pass at a `fields` attribute for dataset objects.  For
instance:

```
import yt
from yt.data_objects.static_output import FieldTypeContainer
ds = yt.load("IsolatedGalaxy/galaxy0030/galaxy0030")
print ds.fields.enzo.Density
```

The result is the field info object for ("enzo", "Density").  This implements
`__dir__` in both levels of the containers, so can be tab-completed.

If this looks interesting, before it goes in I would like to bikeshed whether
this should return the actual field info objects, or if it should return a
sympy object with the FieldInfo object as an attribute.  One reason to explore
this would be to enable common subexpression elimination and the like to build
new derived fields that don't require evaluation of intermediate fields.
title: Add "fields" attribute to datasets

content.raw:
Can we get some tests for this before it gets merged in?

I'm ok with this, but it would be nice if the FieldInfo object itself could get some more sugar. Right now its `__repr__` isn't very useful.
content.html:

content.raw: The sympy object would also work.
content.html: The sympy object would also work.

content.raw:
What do you want for sugar?

As far as the tests, I'll add some.
content.html:
What do you want for sugar?

As far as the tests, I'll add some.

content.raw:
So right now when you interactively look at the `('gas', 'density')` field using this (which I just tested out for the first time and is pretty awesome!), you get something like this:

```
In [2]: ds.fields.gas.density
Out[2]: <yt.fields.derived_field.DerivedField at 0x10c5766d0>
In [3]: print ds.fields.gas.density
<yt.fields.derived_field.DerivedField object at 0x10c5766d0>
```

If I'm a new user, the `__repr__` and `__str__` for the `DerivedField` object mean basically nothing to me. It would be nice if it incorporated some of the information that's attached to the field (e.g. the name, units, whether it's a mesh or particle field, and maybe some of the other information we have).
content.html:
So right now when you interactively look at the ('gas', 'density') field using this (which I just tested out for the first time and is pretty awesome!), you get something like this:

In [2]: ds.fields.gas.density
Out[2]: <yt.fields.derived_field.DerivedField at 0x10c5766d0>
In [3]: print ds.fields.gas.density
<yt.fields.derived_field.DerivedField object at 0x10c5766d0>

If I'm a new user, the __repr__ and __str__ for the DerivedField object mean basically nothing to me. It would be nice if it incorporated some of the information that's attached to the field (e.g. the name, units, whether it's a mesh or particle field, and maybe some of the other information we have).

content.raw: I'm not sure how we should document this. I'm torn between adding a new section in the fields docs and something more invasive to replace uses of `field_list` and `derived_field_list` that would be better suited to this syntax.
content.html: I'm not sure how we should document this. I'm torn between adding a new section in the fields docs and something more invasive to replace uses of field_list and derived_field_list that would be better suited to this syntax.

content.raw: This is spot on.  This seems like really low hanging fruit to just make printing those informative, like showing display name, units, particle_field, etc.
content.html: This is spot on. This seems like really low hanging fruit to just make printing those informative, like showing display name, units, particle_field, etc.

content.raw:
Maybe also include `vector_field`? Not sure whether `take_log` makes sense to include.

I like this format though:


```
#!python

In [4]: ds.fields.all.particle_position_x
Out[4]: Derived Field (all, particle_position_x): (units: code_length, particle field)

In [1]: print ds.fields.gas.density
Derived Field (gas, density): (units: g/cm**3)
```
content.html:
Maybe also include vector_field? Not sure whether take_log makes sense to include.

I like this format though:

In [4]: ds.fields.all.particle_position_x
Out[4]: Derived Field (all, particle_position_x): (units: code_length, particle field)

In [1]: print ds.fields.gas.density
Derived Field (gas, density): (units: g/cm**3)

content.raw:
Should we call on-disk fields "derived"?


```
#!python

In [6]: ds.fields.enzo.Density
Out[6]: Derived Field (enzo, Density): (units: code_mass / code_length**3)
```
content.html:
Should we call on-disk fields "derived"?

In [6]: ds.fields.enzo.Density
Out[6]: Derived Field (enzo, Density): (units: code_mass / code_length**3)

content.raw: Flake8 errors should now be fixed.  I actually don't understand one of them, which was the `assert_almost_equal` error, which to my reading should not have been a problem.  Also, I think one was rather annoying, which was that I reused variable names inside a list comprehension, which was on purpose.  Regardless, should all pass now.
content.html: Flake8 errors should now be fixed. I actually don't understand one of them, which was the assert_almost_equal error, which to my reading should not have been a problem. Also, I think one was rather annoying, which was that I reused variable names inside a list comprehension, which was on purpose. Regardless, should all pass now.

content.raw:
Those were on the other pull request, right?

In any case, list comprehension one was causing a real bug in code that was corrected by one of my style PRs. If you're interested I can dig it up. The gist was that the list comprehension redefined a variable, which was then used later as if the list comprehension *hadn't* redefined the variable. I agree that it's often benign, but if it sometimes causes real bugs I think the rule is worth enforcing.

For the `assert_almost_equal` error, it's because that function wasn't imported from `yt.testing`. It wasn't a problem in 0defa67, however when you merge with the current yt tip (as the test bot does), it becomes an error because the `from yt.testing import *` in that file goes away. You could revert it back to `assert_almost_equal` if you explicitly import it from yt.testing. It might be easier to see why the error is happening if you merge first.
content.html:
Those were on the other pull request, right?

In any case, list comprehension one was causing a real bug in code that was corrected by one of my style PRs. If you're interested I can dig it up. The gist was that the list comprehension redefined a variable, which was then used later as if the list comprehension hadn't redefined the variable. I agree that it's often benign, but if it sometimes causes real bugs I think the rule is worth enforcing.

For the assert_almost_equal error, it's because that function wasn't imported from yt.testing. It wasn't a problem in 0defa67, however when you merge with the current yt tip (as the test bot does), it becomes an error because the from yt.testing import * in that file goes away. You could revert it back to assert_almost_equal if you explicitly import it from yt.testing. It might be easier to see why the error is happening if you merge first.
